docs.lead_paragraph: Often, my psychiatric patients bring carefully recorded dreams to their sessions. They are sophisticated people who have been taught that dream interpretation is part of the therapy drill. After all, Freud singled out dreams as the royal road to the unconscious. A hundred years later, scientists are still unsure what dreams are about, but their very inscrutability suggests that they guard deep truths, that they are the magic keys to the psychic kingdom.

headline.main: Finding Gold In the Jumble Of Dreams

docs.abstract: Dr Anna Fels Cases column relates her use of dreams in therapy and gives examples supporting view that dreams are extensions of core emotional life (M)
docs.snippet: Often, my psychiatric patients bring carefully recorded dreams to their sessions. They are sophisticated people who have been taught that dream interpretation is part of the therapy drill. After all, Freud singled out dreams as the royal road to the...

docs.lead_paragraph: If doctors followed all the government recommendations aimed at preventing disease and injury, they would spend more than seven hours a day on those standards and have almost no time left for actual treatment, researchers have calculated. Writing in The American Journal of Public Health this month, the researchers say the issue will become more important as more screening tests are developed.

headline.main: Doctors Try to Beat the Clock

docs.abstract: Duke University researcher Dr J Lloyd Michener and Dr Kimberly S H Yarnall publish report in American Journal of Public Health that shows doctors following government standards for preventive care would need to spend more than seven hours per day meeting those requirements, leaving little time to spend on actual treatment; suggests changes in administration of medical services; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: If doctors followed all the government recommendations aimed at preventing disease and injury, they would spend more than seven hours a day on those standards and have almost no time left for actual treatment, researchers have calculated.    Writing...

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who has recently lost a loved one to cancer may be inclined to think that little progress has been made in conquering this complex disease. That would be very wrong. The advances in the last 50 years in understanding the causes of cancer and in detecting and treating it have turned many once fatal cancers into curable and, sometimes, preventable diseases.

headline.main: Success Stories Abound in Efforts to Prevent and Control Cancer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses differences in cancer tests, treatments and outcomes since American Cancer Society published first annual study Cancer Facts and Figures 50 years ago; hlds that many types of cancers can now be treated effectively if detected early; contends that statistics prove that routine medical exams and self exams save lives; asserts that smoking causes more cancers than any other single factor and lung cancer is leading cause of death for men and women; notes that childhood cancer deaths have plummeted from 3,200 children in 1953 to estimated 1,500 in 2003 due mainly to innovative treatment therapies; graph (S)
docs.snippet: Anyone who has recently lost a loved one to cancer may be inclined to think that little progress has been made in conquering this complex disease. That would be very wrong.    The advances in the last 50 years in understanding the causes of cancer...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a study that has bearing on how aggressively doctors should treat children with diabetes, researchers have found that extremely low blood sugar does not appear to cause learning problems. Low blood sugar, or hypoglycemia, is more likely to occur among children who are receiving intensive therapy to control their diabetes.
docs.abstract: Nemours Children's Clinic Dr Tim Wysocki study of diabetic children, published in journal Diabetes Care, shows hypoglycemia does not cause learning disabilities, but maintains healthy blood sugar levels are still important; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: In a study that has bearing on how aggressively doctors should treat children with diabetes, researchers have found that extremely low blood sugar does not appear to cause learning problems.    Low blood sugar, or hypoglycemia, is more likely to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Smoking, a known risk factor in strokes caused by blockages of blood to the brain, also appears to play a role in bleeding strokes in men, a new study finds. A report in the current Stroke, an American Heart Association journal, says that men who smoke more than a pack of cigarettes a day have twice the risk of hemorrhagic stroke. These strokes, which occur when ruptured vessels bleed into the brain, account for about 12 percent of strokes. About a third of them are fatal.

headline.main: A New Link to Bleeding Stroke

docs.abstract: Physicians' Health Study findings give basis for research showing connection between smoking and bleeding strokes in men; Dr Tobias Kurth of Brigham and Women's Hospital's study, published in journal Stroke, reports men who smoke more than one pack of cigarettes per day are twice as likely to suffer hemorrhagic stroke than non-smokers; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Smoking, a known risk factor in strokes caused by blockages of blood to the brain, also appears to play a role in bleeding strokes in men, a new study finds.    A report in the current Stroke, an American Heart Association journal, says that men who...

docs.lead_paragraph: Women in menopause are at greater risk of high blood pressure if they have even low levels of lead in their blood, a new study reports. The problem is mainly a result of lead that has built up in the skeleton over a lifetime, and is then released as menopause causes bones to break down and lose minerals, said Dr. Denis Nash, the main researcher.
docs.abstract: Dr Denis Nash reports his University of Maryland School of Medicine research shows that high lead levels in blood of menopausal women correlate to high blood pressure; says that build-up of lead over time is released as bones break down and lose minerals; contends that treatment for bone loss could reduce lead dispersal; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Women in menopause are at greater risk of high blood pressure if they have even low levels of lead in their blood, a new study reports.    The problem is mainly a result of lead that has built up in the skeleton over a lifetime, and is then released...

docs.lead_paragraph: It took only a few dry coughs to spread a mysterious respiratory illness to clusters of health workers in Asia and to kill the World Health Organization doctor who first identified it. And it took only a few airplane passengers for the illness to reach 15 countries in Asia, North America and Europe. Now, one person has apparently spread the illness to scores of residents of an apartment complex in Hong Kong, and the government has put the entire complex in isolation and closed all schools. In Toronto, two hospitals have been closed to new patients.

headline.main: Step by Step, Scientists Track Mystery Ailment

docs.abstract: World Health Organization creates network of 11 laboratories in 9 countries to investigate SARS, after it declares SARS worldwide health threat on March 15; scientists have many questions yet to be answered in order to control new virus including data on transmission and origin; outline of outbreak and map charting infection of 249 people from one SARS infected person emphasize scope of potentially deadly syndrome; two diagnostic tests have been developed, but require more study to determine accuracy of results; photo; map; chart (L)
docs.snippet: It took only a few dry coughs to spread a mysterious respiratory illness to clusters of health workers in Asia and to kill the World Health Organization doctor who first identified it. And it took only a few airplane passengers for the illness to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. James Edward Muller does not look like a rabble rouser. A cardiologist and the associate director of the Center for Integration of Medicine and Innovative Technology, at Massachusetts General Hospital, Dr. Muller has the contemplative demeanor of a man who once considered the priesthood, drawn by the beauty and mysticism of the Mass.

headline.main: Doctor for Peace Gains Power for Laity

docs.abstract: Dr James Edward Muller, cardiologist and social activist, answers questions about his founding of Roman Catholic action group Voice of Faithful and its message; research into vunerable plaques, heart attack trends and triggers and his widening efforts toward prevention of nuclear war are discussed; photo (M)

keywords.value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I am being harassed by the guy next door and I want him to stop,'' the woman in my office said with firm conviction. The man would leer at her in the elevator just to make her squirm, she said. But when I inquired further, she described a lingering feeling of being mistreated by people she said were jealous of her. She was even sure that someone had once tried to poison her.

headline.main: Self-Protection or Delusion? The Many Varieties of Paranoia

docs.abstract: Paranoid behavoirs are somewhat common and in varying degrees and situations could prove beneficial; true paranoia, however, is psychotic condition often linked with schizophrenia; New York Weill Cornell Center brain scan research done by Drs David Silbersweig and Jane Epstein show increased activity in amygdala, area of brain that processes fear and danger, in paranoid schizophrenics and decreased activity in prefrontal cortex, which effects our ability to classify thoughts and responses; drawing (M)
